definition:
A concept is an abstract idea that serves as a foundation for more concrete principles, thoughts, and beliefs.
Concepts play an important role in all aspects of cognition. As such, concepts are studied within such disciplines as linguistics, psychology, and philosophy, and these disciplines are interested in the logical and psychological structure of concepts, and how they are put together to form thoughts and sentences. The study of concepts has served as an important flagship of an emerging interdisciplinary approach, cognitive science.
In contemporary philosophy, three understandings of a concept prevail:

mental representations, such that a concept is an entity that exists in the mind (a mental object)
abilities peculiar to cognitive agents (mental states)
Fregean senses, abstract objects rather than a mental object or a mental state
Concepts are classified into a hierarchy, higher levels of which are termed "superordinate" and lower levels termed "subordinate". Additionally, there is the "basic" or "middle" level at which people will most readily categorize a concept. For example, a basic-level concept would be "chair", with its superordinate, "furniture", and its subordinate, "easy chair".
Concepts may be exact or inexact. When the mind makes a generalization such as the concept of tree, it extracts similarities from numerous examples; the simplification enables higher-level thinking. A concept is instantiated (reified) by all of its actual or potential instances, whether these are things in the real world or other ideas.
Concepts are studied as components of human cognition in the cognitive science disciplines of linguistics, psychology, and philosophy, where an ongoing debate asks whether all cognition must occur through concepts. Concepts are regularly formalized in mathematics, computer science, databases and artificial intelligence. Examples of specific high-level conceptual classes in these fields include classes, schema or categories. In informal use, the word concept can refer to any idea.

definition: Abatement ab initio (Latin for "from the beginning") is a common law legal doctrine that states that the death of a defendant who is appealing a criminal conviction extinguishes all criminal proceedings initiated against that defendant from indictment through conviction. Abatement ab initio was the subject of two United States Supreme Court decisions, Durham v. United States (1971) and Dove v. United States (1976). The former extended the doctrine to cases where certiorari was pending and not yet granted, and the latter excluded discretionary appeals.

As the news of James' passing spread, the court faced a unique challenge. They had to apply the legal concept of 'Abatement ab initio'. This ancient legal doctrine, derived from Latin, was designed to address this exact situation. It states that when a defendant dies before a final judgment is made on their case, the entire legal process initiated against them from the beginning becomes void.

The court, following this principle, decided to vacate James' conviction. The long, arduous trial and subsequent appeal were erased, leaving no criminal record for James. His name remained clean, and the town he loved could continue to see him as the generous baker they had always known.

While the outcome was saddening for those who thought James guilty, it served as a reminder of the importance of this ancient legal principle that ensures justice isn't unfairly served when circumstances change in an unexpected way.

definition:
An abstention doctrine is any of several doctrines that a United States court may (or in some cases must) apply to refuse to hear a case if hearing the case would potentially intrude upon the powers of another court. Such doctrines are usually invoked where lawsuits involving the same issues are brought in two different court systems at the same time (such as federal and state courts).
The United States has a federal court system with limitations on the cases that it can hear, while each state has its own individual court system. In some instances, the jurisdiction of these courts overlap, so a lawsuit between two parties may be brought in either or both courts. The latter circumstance can lead to confusion, waste resources, as well as cause the appearance that one court is disrespecting the other. Both federal and state courts have developed rules determining when one court will defer to another's jurisdiction over a particular case.

Title: A Matter of Justice: A Clash of Jurisdictions

In the peaceful town of Bridgewood, a local business, TW's Tech Shop, was embroiled in a heated dispute with a major tech company, HighTech Inc. The heart of the conflict was over a patent infringement claim by TW's Tech Shop, alleging that HighTech Inc. had copied a unique design for their latest smartphone case.

The case was a complex one, but TW's Tech Shop, as a small business owner, did not have the resources to tackle both the state and federal courts. With that in mind, they filed a lawsuit in the Bridgewood County Court, the state court, hoping for a fair resolution.

Meanwhile, HighTech Inc., a multinational corporation, was confident that the federal court was the better forum to contest the claims, believing they might find more favorable jurisdiction there. A week later, they filed a nearly identical lawsuit in the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Bridgewood.

Upon learning this, the judge in the Bridgewood County Court, while sympathetic to TW's Tech Shop, decided to abide by the Abstention Doctrine. Recognizing that TW's Tech Shop could not sustain two separate and expensive lawsuits, the judge restrained himself from proceeding with the case, acknowledging that the federal court's jurisdiction and resources would be more suitable to resolve this multifaceted dispute.

Thus, the Abstention Doctrine came into play, demonstrating the ability of our courts to show respect for each other's roles, prevents excess litigation, and steers justice in a more efficient direction for all parties concerned. It served as a reminder that in the pursuit of justice, deference and coordination often create the best outcomes.

The abstention doctrine prevented both courts from overstepping their jurisdictions, ensuring that the dispute was resolved efficiently and with proper application of the relevant laws. In the end, the state court issued a ruling that was binding on both parties, avoiding the confusion and waste of resources that could have resulted from simultaneous proceedings in both courts.

definition: The abstract system of title transfer (German: Abstraktionsprinzip) is a legal term in German law relating to the law of obligations (Schuldrecht) and property law (Sachenrecht). Although no express reference to it is made in the German Civil Code (BGB), the concept of separating a personal undertaking to pay or exchange goods or legal rights (e.g. through contract) from the conveyance of title to those goods or legal rights (e.g. through a deed or land registration) is fundamental to German private law (as well as Brazilian law, Greek law, South African law, and Scots law).

Title: The Art Forgery and the Absent Artist

In the bustling heart of Berlin, a renowned art gallery, 'Van Gogh's Vision,' was known for showcasing rare, authentic works by famous artists. One day, a local artist named Otto, struggling to sell his modern art, decided to create a perfect forgery of a priceless Van Gogh painting, "Starry Night," and sell it to the gallery's owner, Herr Schmidt.

Otto expertly replicated the painting, complete with stellar brushstrokes and the unmistakable swirls of the night sky. Herr Schmidt, upon seeing the forgery, was dazzled and, blinded by greed, bought it instantly, paying Otto a hefty sum.

However, the joy was short-lived.wordpress.com/2015/12/31/the-abstraction-principle-understanding-how-contracts-and-property-work/
When police raided the gallery, they discovered Otto's forgery and arrested him. The genuine "Starry Night" was safely tucked away at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam. Herr Schmidt was left with a forgery and a hefty loss.

This unfortunate situation illustrates the Abstraction Principle in law. Otto had the obligation (personal undertaking) to sell the genuine painting, but not the right (title) to it. The transaction, while legally binding (Otto received payment), failed due to the lack of the actual painting, which was rightfully owned by the Van Gogh Museum.

In this example, the art work (goods) and the promise to sell it (the personal undertaking) were separated. The Abstraction Principle helps us understand that in a contract, the ownership of goods or rights, and the agreement to exchange them, are two separate things.

Meet Emma, a young entrepreneur who owns a small bakery. She decides to expand her business by partnering with her friend, Alex, to open a new store in a popular shopping district. They agree to split the profits 50/50 and create a joint venture.

To formalize their partnership, they sign a partnership agreement, which outlines their roles, responsibilities, and profit sharing. However, the agreement does not transfer the title to the new store. The deed to the property remains with Emma, as she is the one who purchased it.

Six months later, Alex wants to withdraw from the partnership. Emma, feeling frustrated, tries to force Alex to sell their share of the business. But Alex refuses, claiming that they never intended to transfer their share of the profit stream.

Here's where the abstraction principle kicks in. Even though Emma owns the deed, she cannot force Alex to relinquish their claim to the profits. The abstraction principle separates the transfer of title (the deed) from the personal undertaking to perform certain obligations (the partnership agreement). This means that Alex's agreement to share profits is a separate entity from the property itself.

In this scenario, Emma can choose to buy out Alex's share of the business or find a new partner, but she cannot force Alex to give up their claim to the profits. The abstraction principle ensures that the legal relationship between parties is separated from the physical property, allowing for flexibility and clarity in complex transactions.

definition: In law, acquiescence occurs when a person knowingly stands by, without raising any objection to, the infringement of their rights, while someone else unknowingly and without malice aforethought acts in a manner inconsistent with their rights. As a result of acquiescence, the person whose rights are infringed may lose the ability to make a legal claim against the infringer, or may be unable to obtain an injunction against continued infringement. The doctrine infers a form of "permission" that results from silence or passiveness over an extended period of time.

Years passed, and the café's popularity continued to grow. The opera house's visitor count remained low, and Mrs. Johnson, while still hoping for a rise in the number of patrons, continued to support and promote the café.

One day, Mr. Roberts, blissfully unaware of the initial issue, decided to expand Café Libro all the way onto the opera house's footpath, creating a significant obstruction for Mrs. Johnson's patrons. Alas, Mrs. Johnson didn't object because she had been acquiescing, unknowingly consenting to Mr. Roberts' actions through her silence and passive acceptance.

When Mrs. Johnson, out of necessity, threatened legal action against Mr. Roberts, he was bewildered. Through years of acquiescence, Mrs. Johnson had, in the eyes of the law, given tacit permission for the infringement of her rights.

This story illustrates the legal concept of acquiescence. When we knowingly stand by without raising objections, we may inadvertently allow others to infringe on our rights, making it difficult to seek legal recourse or obtain an injunction against continued infringement. It's a reminder that silence and passiveness over an extended period can be interpreted as permission.

definition:
The act-of-state doctrine is a principle in international law whereby acts done by a state in its own territory cannot be challenged by the national courts of another state.
As a principle of federal common law in the United States which states, in circumstances where it applies, that courts in the United States will not rule on the validity of another government's (formal) sovereign act with respect to property located within the latter's own territory. The act-of-state doctrine enters consideration most often in cases where a foreign sovereign has expropriated the property of a U.S. national located in that foreign territory (e.g. through nationalization).

definition: Actio libera in causa (frequently abbreviated as a.l.i.c., Latin for "action free in its cause") is a law principle in a typical Western law system (both common law and civil law). The doctrine means that even if the person was not free to choose the course of action while performing an offence, he can still be held responsible for it if he voluntarily created a condition ("cause") for the offending action. A typical example is self-defense: in Anglo-American jurisdictions lethal action is justified under certain circumstances while protecting oneself, others, or property. However, this defense is not available, for example, to a person who started the fight, thus creating a "cause" for killing in self-defense at a later time. Most frequently a.l.i.c. is mentioned with regard to voluntary intoxication: if a person gets drunk, she will not be able use her state of inebriation to claim that, for example, her act of negligence was an accident.

Title: The Case of the Rowdy Pub Brawl

In the quaint town of Millford, the locally-renowned pub, "The Mug 'n' Malt," was bustling with patrons enjoying a Friday night out. Among them were two long-time friends, George and Henry, who had a notorious reputation for their rivalry.

One evening, a heated argument between them escalated, prompting Henry to challenge George to a friendly arm-wrestling contest. The crowd gathered, egging them on. The contest quickly became heated, and in a fit of anger, Henry punched George.

Despite the spectacle, the pub's bouncer, a notoriously large and calm man named Tom, seemed unfazed. As the violence escalated, Tom made an unusual choice - he decided to take a shot of whiskey. Minutes later, fueled by the alcohol, Tom intervened, using excessive force and breaking up the fight. In the chaos, a glass shattered, and a piece of shard struck George, causing a severe injury.

George sued Tom, claiming that the pub bouncer was responsible for his injuries, as he had created the "cause" of the fight and was then negligent by using alcohol to escalate the situation, compromising his ability to react rationally.

In court, the defense argued that Tom's actions were voluntary and he was responsible for the conditions he created. They argued that, despite being intoxicated, Tom was still accountable for his decisions and actions. In the end, the jury agreed, and Tom was found responsible for George's injuries because he voluntarily created the cause of the altercation that led to the unfortunate event. The verdict served as a reminder to not underestimate the legal responsibility that comes with creating a volatile situation, even when under the influence.

Alex was held responsible for his actions, illustrating the legal principle of actio libera in causa: even if the person was not free to choose the course of action while performing the offence, they can still be held responsible if they voluntarily created the condition that led to the offending action.

definition:
An agent of record (AOR) is an individual or legal entity with a duly executed contractual agreement with an insurance policy owner in line with the prevailing legal norms and regulations of the region in which the contract was entered. The agent of record has a legal right to receive commissions from the respective insurance policy.
The agent of record is authorized to represent an insured party in purchasing, servicing, and maintaining insurance coverage with a designated insurer. The majority of insurance companies will not disclose information or discuss an insured party's account with an agent other than the agent of record. An insured party wishing to change its insurance agent must properly authorize the insurer to release their information and discuss their coverage with their newly appointed agent, for example with an agent of record letter.
Relevant documents may be executed via hard copy or electronically (in jurisdictions where electronic execution is legal). Applications may be made electronically, as well as in physical form.

definition:
The Aggregate effects doctrine, Cumulative effects doctrine, or substantial effects doctrine is a legal doctrine in United States federal law. The AED permits extension of the regulation of interstate commerce into any action which affects interstate commerce only when aggregated with other actions. It is most often associated with Wickard v. Filburn (1942).: 125  In Wickard a wheat farmer growing wheat solely for animal feed within the confines of his own farm was found to be regulatable because private growth for private consumption was the primary reason for decrease of demand.: 125 
Although mostly associated with Wickard, it is also referred to as "substantial effects" in another formative case the preceding year called U.S. v. Darby Lumber Co. (1941).: 126  In the previous term the same idea was the reasoning for the decision of  National Labor Relations Board v. Fainblatt . In Fainblatt the "plenary" power of interstate regulation "extends to all such commerce be it great or small" and had never been held "to be constitutionally restricted because in any particular case the volume of the commerce affected may be small."
Since its introduction this doctrine has been applied widely. One common example is alcohol laws, such as Michigan's well known wine shipment restrictions;  it is the basis of the influential NFIB v. Sebelius (2012) and some experts apply aggregate effects to the abortion law debate.
This doctrine is differently applied in tax and other cases and its effects upon firm decisions to enter or not enter interstate markets remains unclear.

Title: "The Baker's Bountiful Bread"

In the quaint town of Maplewood, nestled between the hills, lived a humble baker named Sam. Sam's bakery was known far and wide for its delicious, freshly baked bread. No matter the day, there was always a line outside his shop, with locals and travelers alike clamoring for a taste of Sam's artisanal loaves.

One year, Sam, a proud independent entrepreneur, decided to take things a step further. He cultivated a small plot behind his bakery, growing the grains needed for his bread. This move was intended to cut costs and ensure the freshest, most authentic ingredients for his customers.

Yet, the local government intervened. Reason being, Sam's small grain farm was now a threat to the large supply chain of national bakeries, hidden beneath the aggregate effect of numerous individual farmers like Sam. The local government argued that, if left unregulated, small farmers could disrupt the market, affecting the supply of grains to the larger bakeries, leading to increased grain costs, and ultimately, higher prices for consumers.

In this case, Sam's small, individual farming activity might seem insignificant, but the government had the power to regulate it under the Aggregate Effects Doctrine. The principle here is that, even if a single action may appear minor, when combined with many similar actions, it could have a significant impact on interstate commerce. Sam's wheat farming, while meant for self-consumption, contributed to the market and, thus, fell under government jurisdiction.

This illustrates how the Aggregate Effects Doctrine allows governments to regulate activities that may seem local but can cumulatively influence interstate commerce. With the doctrine, they can ensure continuity and stability in the market, even on small scales. On the flipside, it can cause concern over the potential unintended consequences of too much regulation on individual freedoms. Regardless, it's an essential legal doctrine that balances the needs of commerce and individual liberty in regulating interstate activities.

definition: Alternative liability is a legal doctrine that allows a plaintiff to shift the burden of proving causation of their injury to multiple defendants, even though only one of them could have been responsible. The leading case showing the principle of alternative liability in action is Summers v. Tice, where the two defendants negligently shot in the direction of the plaintiff and two pellets caused the plaintiff's injury, one in the right eye and one in the upper lip. In the interests of justice, the innocent plaintiff's case is not defeated because they cannot prove which party was the actual cause (but-for cause) of their injury.

definition: The assignment of income doctrine is a judicial doctrine developed in United States case law by courts trying to limit tax evasion.  The assignment of income doctrine seeks to "preserve the progressive rate structure of the Code by prohibiting the splitting of income among taxable entities."

Since she didn't make enough money herself, she'd have to pay very little tax on the income she received from John. They called it a "gift."

One day, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) caught wind of their arrangement. In their eyes, it seemed less like a gift and more like an attempt to evade taxes. The IRS applied the Assignment of Income Doctrine, a law designed to prevent just this kind of maneuver.

On the day they met with the IRS agent, John and Lisa were visibly upset. They'd been under the impression their plan would help them navigate the tax system more favorably. The agent explained that the Assignment of Income Doctrine exists to maintain income tax fairness. By avoiding the progressive tax rates designed to tax the wealthiest people at a higher rate, their plan went against the intention of the law.

In the end, John and Lisa agreed to restructure their finances with the IRS. Learning about the Assignment of Income Doctrine allowed them to understand the importance of fair taxation and avoid potential legal consequences. The doctrine ensures that income is reported and taxed based on the individual's true economic position, rather than artificially dividing it among multiple parties to avoid taxes.

definition:
In legal terminology, the assured clear distance ahead (ACDA) is the distance ahead of any terrestrial locomotive device such as a land vehicle, typically an automobile, or watercraft, within which they should be able to bring the device to a halt. It is one of the most fundamental principles governing ordinary care and the duty of care for all methods of conveyance, and is frequently used to determine if a driver is in proper control and is a nearly universally implicit consideration in vehicular accident liability. The rule is a precautionary trivial burden required to avert the great probable gravity of precious life loss and momentous damage. Satisfying the ACDA rule is necessary but not sufficient to comply with the more generalized basic speed law, and accordingly, it may be used as both a layman's criterion and judicial test for courts to use in determining if a particular speed is negligent, but not to prove it is safe. As a spatial standard of care, it also serves as required explicit and fair notice of prohibited conduct so unsafe speed laws are not void for vagueness. The concept has transcended into accident reconstruction and engineering.
This distance is typically both determined and constrained by the proximate edge of clear visibility, but it may be attenuated to a margin of which beyond hazards may reasonably be expected to spontaneously appear. The rule is the specific spatial case of the common law basic speed rule, and an application of volenti non fit injuria. The two-second rule may be the limiting factor governing the ACDA, when the speed of forward traffic is what limits the basic safe speed, and a primary hazard of collision could result from following any closer.
As the original common law driving rule preceding statutized traffic law, it is an ever important foundational rule in today's complex driving environment. Because there are now protected classes of roadway users—such as a school bus, mail carrier, emergency vehicle, horse-drawn vehicle, agricultural machinery, street sweeper, disabled vehicle, cyclist, and pedestrian—as well as natural hazards which may occupy or obstruct the roadway beyond the edge of visibility, negligence may not depend ex post facto on what a driver happened to hit, could not have known, but had a concurrent duty to avoid. Furthermore, modern knowledge of human factors has revealed physiological limitations—such as the subtended angular velocity detection threshold (SAVT)—which may make it difficult, and in some circumstance impossible, for other drivers to always comply with right-of-way statutes by staying clear of roadway.

definition:
The attractive nuisance doctrine applies to the law of torts in some jurisdictions. It states that a landowner may be held liable for injuries to children trespassing on the land if the injury is caused by an object on the land that is likely to attract children.  The doctrine is designed to protect children who are unable to appreciate the risk posed by the object, by imposing a liability on the landowner. The doctrine has been applied to hold landowners liable for injuries caused by abandoned cars, piles of lumber or sand, trampolines, and swimming pools. However, it can be applied to virtually anything on the property.
There is no set cutoff point that defines youth. The courts will evaluate each "child" on a case-by-case basis to see if the "child" qualifies as a youth. If it is determined that the child was able to understand and appreciate the hazard, the doctrine of attractive nuisance will not likely apply.
Under the old common law, the plaintiff (either the child, or a parent suing on the child's behalf) had to show that it was the hazardous condition itself which lured the child onto the landowner's property. However, most jurisdictions have statutorily altered this condition, and now require only that the injury was foreseeable by the landowner.

definition: Doctrines of attribution are legal doctrines by which liability is extended to a defendant who did not actually commit the criminal act.: 347  : 665  Examples include vicarious liability (when acts of another are imputed or "attributed" to a defendant), attempt to commit a crime (even though it was never completed), and conspiracy to commit a crime (when it is not completed or which is committed by another in the conspiracy).: 665

definition:
Audi alteram partem (or audiatur et altera pars) is a Latin phrase meaning "listen to the other side", or "let the other side be heard as well". It is the principle that no person should be judged without a fair hearing in which each party is given the opportunity to respond to the evidence against them.
"Audi alteram partem" is considered to be a principle of fundamental justice or equity or the principle of natural justice in most legal systems. This principle includes the rights of a party or its lawyers to confront the witnesses against them, to have a fair opportunity to challenge the evidence presented by the other party, to summon one's own witnesses and to present evidence, and to have counsel, if necessary at public expense, in order to make one's case properly.

Enraged, Sam approached the authorities, claiming that The Sweet Spot had stolen his wife's recipe. The town officials, eager to keep peace in their peaceful town, called upon the mayor to resolve the dispute.

Ignoring the old adage "Audi alteram partem," the mayor hastily ordered the closure of The Sweet Spot, declaring them guilty and without a fair hearing. The bakery's owner, Maria, was shocked and devastated. With mounting legal fees, she felt trapped and helpless.

The town's attorney, Grace, a champion of justice, noticed the unjust treatment of Maria and decided to step in. She reminded everyone of the importance of the principle, "Audi alteram partem" — to listen to both sides and give each party a fair opportunity to respond to the evidence against them.

Grace explained that a ruling made without hearing Maria's side would be unjust and against the basic notions of fairness. The mayor agreed, and a hearing was scheduled with both bakers.

During the hearing, Maria presented evidence showing the popularity of the pastry in question before her bakery opened, thus proving her recipe was unique and original. Sam admitted that the taste was reminiscent of his wife's pastry but could not prove that Maria had stolen the recipe.

With "Audi alteram partem" at the forefront, the mayor made a ruling that neither bakery was guilty of recipe theft. The Sweet Spot was allowed to resume business, and the town continued to enjoy its beloved pastries without further rivalry. The people of Baker's Corner learned the importance of giving each party a fair opportunity to be heard, fostering a greater sense of justice and harmony in their community.

definition:
The basic structure doctrine is a common law legal doctrine that the constitution of a sovereign state has certain characteristics that cannot be erased by its legislature. The doctrine is recognised in India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, and  Uganda. It was developed by the Supreme Court of India in a series of constitutional law cases in the 1960s and 1970s that culminated in Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala, where the doctrine was formally adopted. Bangladesh is perhaps the only legal system in the world that recognizes this doctrine in an expressed, written and rigid constitutional manner through Article 7B of its Constitution.
In Kesavananda Bharati, Justice Hans Raj Khanna propounded that the Constitution of India contains certain basic features that cannot be altered or destroyed through amendments by the Parliament of India. Key among these "basic features", as expounded by Justice Khanna, are the fundamental rights guaranteed to individuals by the constitution. The doctrine thus forms the basis of the Supreme Court of India's power to review and strike down constitutional amendments and acts enacted by the Parliament that conflict with or seek to alter this "basic structure" of the Constitution. The basic features of the Constitution have not been explicitly defined by the Judiciary, and the determination of any particular feature as a "basic" feature is made by the Court on a case-by-case basis.
The Supreme Court's initial position on constitutional amendments had been that any part of the Constitution was amendable and that the Parliament might, by passing a Constitution Amendment Act in compliance with the requirements of article 368, amend any provision of the Constitution, including the Fundamental Rights and article 368.
In 1967, the Supreme Court reversed its earlier decisions in Golaknath v. State of Punjab. It held that Fundamental Rights included in Part III of the Constitution are given a "transcendental position" and are beyond the reach of Parliament. It also declared any amendment that "takes away or abridges" a Fundamental Right conferred by Part III as unconstitutional. In 1973, the basic structure doctrine was formally introduced with rigorous legal reasoning in Justice Hans Raj Khanna's decisive judgment in the landmark decision of Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala. Previously, the Supreme Court had held that the power of Parliament to amend the Constitution was unfettered. However, in this landmark ruling, the Court adjudicated that while Parliament has "wide" powers, it did not have the power to destroy or emasculate the basic elements or fundamental features of the constitution.
Although Kesavananda was decided by a narrow margin of 7–6, the basic structure doctrine, as propounded in Justice Khanna's judgement, has since gained widespread legal and scholarly acceptance due to a number of subsequent cases and judgments relying heavily upon it to strike down Parliamentary amendments that were held to be violative of the basic structure and therefore unconstitutional. Primary among these was the imposition of a state of emergency by Indira Gandhi in 1975, and her subsequent attempt to suppress her prosecution through the 39th Amendment. When the Kesavananda case was decided, the underlying apprehension of the majority bench that elected representatives could not be trusted to act responsibly was perceived as unprecedented. However, the passage of the 39th Amendment by the Indian National Congress' majority in central and state legislatures, proved that in fact such apprehension was well-grounded. In Indira Nehru Gandhi v. Raj Narain and Minerva Mills v. Union of India, Constitution Benches of the Supreme Court used the basic structure doctrine to strike down the 39th Amendment and parts of the 42nd Amendment respectively, and paved the way for restoration of Indian democracy.
The Supreme Court's position on constitutional amendments laid out in its judgements is that Parliament can amend the Constitution but cannot destroy its "basic structure".
The basic structure doctrine was rejected by the High Court of Singapore. It was initially also rejected by the Federal Court of Malaysia, but was later accepted by it. Conversely, the doctrine was initially approved in Belize by the Supreme Court but was later reversed on appeal by the Belize Court of Appeal.

definition:
Beneficium inventarii (literally benefit of the inventory) is a legal doctrine introduced into Roman law by Justinian I to limit the liability of heirs resulting from an insolvent estate.
The beneficium inventarii (French: bénéfice d'invenataire) also occurred in article 793 of the Napoleonic Code (1804), which became the basis of most of the following civil codes, in force in countries such as France and Italy.
The doctrine, which is in force today in many civil law systems, applies to both wills and intestate successions. An heir may accept a succession under beneficium inventarii without being liable for the debts attaching to the estate or to the claims of legatees beyond the estate's value as previously determined by inventory.

Title: A Legacy Penny Saved: The Tale of Jean-Pierre and Marie

In the picturesque French countryside, a humble vineyard was passed down from generation to generation. The latest owner was Jean-Pierre, a hardworking man who tended the vines with love and care.

Sadly, during one of the harshest winters, the vineyard was struck with a devastating disease, leaving it barren and worthless. That summer, Jean-Pierre passed away, leaving behind his daughter Marie, who inherited the vineyard.

Marie was distressed; she loved the land but knew it was no longer worth anything. Crying in the vineyard, she pondered her options when her neighbor, Claire, a well-respected lawyer, came to console her. She suggested that they go through the process of "beneficium inventarii."

Claire explained that beneficium inventarii was a way for Marie to accept the inheritance without being responsible for the vineyard's debts or any claims from other family members. Intrigued and relieved, Marie agreed to follow Claire's advice.

Together, they compiled an inventory of the vineyard, determining its worthless state. The court recognized the inventory and Marie was granted the vineyard under beneficium inventarii. The creditors could no longer chase her for any outstanding debts, as the vineyard's value didn't exceed its recorded worth.

At last, Marie breathed a sigh of relief and hugged Claire tightly. The weight of the vineyard's financial burden was lifted, allowing her to preserve it and hope for a better future. It was there that Marie decided she would rejuvenate the vineyard, nurturing it back to health in memory of her father.

And so, with the protection of beneficium inventarii, Marie's dream continued. She learned the value of a legal doctrine that allowed her a fresh start, one free from the chains of insolvency and full of endless possibility.

definition: Best interests or best interests of the child is a child rights principle, which derives from Article 3 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which says that "in all actions concerning children, whether undertaken by public or private social welfare institutions, courts of law, administrative authorities or legislative bodies, the best interests of the child shall be a primary consideration". Assessing the best interests of a child means to evaluate and balance "all the elements necessary to make a decision in a specific situation for a specific individual child or group of children".

definition: The blue pencil doctrine is a legal concept in common law countries in which a court finds that portions of a contract are void or unenforceable, but other portions of the contract are enforceable. The blue pencil rule allows the legally valid enforceable provisions of the contract to stand despite the nullification of the legally void unenforceable provisions. However, the revised version must represent the original meaning. The rule may not be invoked, for example, to delete the word "not" and thereby change a negative to a positive.

Unfortunately, Sam, an architect by trade, was overzealous in his optimization of the renovation budget. Despite this, the contract mentioned no specific provisions outlining the selection of materials, as both assumed they would work collaboratively.

As expected, the roof started to leak during the first winter, causing extensive water damage to the mansion. definition: The boulevard rule is a principle in United States traffic law which states that the driver of a vehicle entering a highway from a smaller road or entrance (called the unfavored driver) must stop and yield the right of way to all highway traffic (the favored drivers).  The rule often comes into play in road accident cases, when a court must determine if a driver is negligent in causing a collision, due to his breach of the duty of care imposed by the rule on the unfavored driver.

definition:
In the legal system of the United States, a Brady disclosure consists of exculpatory or impeaching information and evidence that is material to the guilt or innocence or to the punishment of a defendant. The term comes from the 1963 U.S. Supreme Court case Brady v. Maryland, in which the Supreme Court ruled that suppression by the prosecution of evidence favorable to a defendant who has requested it violates due process. 
Following Brady, the prosecutor must disclose evidence or information that would prove the innocence of the defendant or would enable the defense to more effectively impeach the credibility of government witnesses. Evidence that would serve to reduce the defendant's sentence must also be disclosed by the prosecution. In practice, this doctrine has often proved difficult to enforce. Some states have established their own laws to try to strengthen enforcement against prosecutorial misconduct in this area.

definition:
In a legal dispute, one party has the burden of proof to show that they are correct, while the other party has no such burden and is presumed to be correct. The burden of proof requires a party to produce evidence to establish the truth of facts needed to satisfy all the required legal elements of the dispute. It is also known as the onus of proof.
The burden of proof is usually on the person who brings a claim in a dispute. It is often associated with the Latin maxim semper necessitas probandi incumbit ei qui agit, a translation of which is: "the necessity of proof always lies with the person who lays charges." In civil suits, for example, the plaintiff bears the burden of proof that the defendant's action or inaction caused injury to the plaintiff, and the defendant bears the burden of proving an affirmative defense. The burden of proof is on the prosecutor for criminal cases, and the defendant is presumed innocent. If the claimant fails to discharge the burden of proof to prove their case, the claim will be dismissed.

definition: In the United States, the Hand formula, also known as the Hand rule, calculus of negligence, or BPL formula, is a conceptual formula created by Judge Learned Hand which describes a process for determining whether a legal duty of care has been breached (see negligence).  The original description of the calculus was in United States v. Carroll Towing Co., in which an improperly secured barge had drifted away from a pier and caused damage to several other boats.

Title: The Unanchored Kayak: A Tale of Negligence

In the heart of picturesque Lake Serene, amidst a bustling summer day, a tragic incident occurred. Jake, an enthusiastic kayaker, had rented a kayak from Shoreline Rentals to explore the serene lake. Unbeknownst to him, the rental company had failed to properly secure the kayak with an anchor before he set off on his adventure.

As Jake paddled further into the lake, a sudden gust of wind came, snatching his unsecured kayak away. Sighting the drifting kayak, a group of boats attempted to maneuver around it but unfortunately, one of them collided, causing significant damage. The boat's owner, Ann, was left with a costly repair bill and a question on her mind: who was at fault?

During the ensuing trial, the judge, like Judge Learned Hand in the Carroll Towing case, applied the 'Calculus of Negligence', a formula to determine if Shoreline Rentals had breached their duty of care towards Jake and, indirectly, towards Ann.

The judge considered two main factors: the probability of the harm occurring (a gust of wind was common on Lake Serene) and the gravity of the potential harm (a damaged kayak posed a collision risk). He also evaluated the burden of taking precautions (securing the kayak with an anchor was within Shoreline Rentals' capability) and the consequences of taking those precautions (it would have slowed down Jake's rental process just a little).

Using these factors, the judge determined that the probability and gravity of harm were high, the burden of taking precautions was slight, and the harm could have been significantly mitigated by taking those precautions. Thus, he ruled in favor of Ann, holding Shoreline Rentals liable for the incident.

The 'Calculus of Negligence' Yet again, proven a useful tool to help balance the scales of justice, protecting citizens from avoidable harm.

Jane and Sarah test out some laptops, and Jane decides she wants to buy one. Sarah convinces Jane to let her sign the contract on behalf of Jane, promising to give Jane the money afterwards.

Unbeknownst to Jane, the store requires all customers to be at least 18 years old to enter into a contract, which is a testament to their legal capacity to do so. Jane, being underage, does not have the legal capacity to enter into a contract on her own. Sarah, being of age, has the legal capacity to enter into a contract, but she has no authority to bind Jane to a contract without her consent.

Later, the store tries to collect payment from Jane, but she refuses, saying she never intended to buy the laptop. The store sues Jane and her parents for breach of contract. In court, the judge rules that Jane did not have the legal capacity to enter into a contract with the store, and therefore, the contract is void. The judge orders the store to return the laptop to Jane and pays Jane's parents to settle the matter.

This story illustrates the legal concept of capacity, highlighting that a person's age and authority can impact their ability to enter into a contract and take on legal obligations. While Jane had the ability to make a decision about buying a laptop, she lacked the legal capacity to enter into a binding contract due to her age.

definition: The Carltona doctrine (or Carltona principle) expresses the idea that, in United Kingdom law, the acts of government departmental officials are synonymous with the actions of the minister in charge of that department. The point was established in Carltona Ltd v Commissioners of Works.

Title: The Misplaced Statue: A Tale of Carltona Doctrine

In the quaint town of Bridlington, renowned for its beautiful seaside, stood a stunning 16th-century statue of Queen Elizabeth I. The statue, a cherished part of the town's heritage, was cared for by the Bridlington Heritage Trust, a government-funded organization under the Ministry of Culture.

One fateful day, the statue mysteriously disappeared from its spot. The trust, overwhelmed by the loss, immediately notified the local police and the Ministry of Culture. The minister in charge of the ministry, a passionate art-lover himself, took personal interest in the case. He appointed a dedicated official, Mr. Higgins, to work closely with the police to find the missing statue.

Weeks passed, and despite the exhaustive search, the statue was nowhere to be found. Frustrated, the minister decided to take action. He issued a directive for all government departments to cooperate in the search, using resources from various departments, such as the Royal Navy for a thorough sea search, and the military to scour the town's outskirts.

A few days later, a local art dealer, Mr. Thompson, kidnapped the statue, intending to sell it for a fortune. Unbeknownst to him, the minister's official, Mr. Higgins, was posing as a potential buyer. After securing the statue, Mr. Higgins arranged for its recovery by the police.

In the court case that followed, it was established that Mr. Higgins' actions, as the minister's representative, could be seen as the minister's own actions under the Carltona doctrine. The court ruled in favor of the Bridlington Heritage Trust and returned the stolen statue, emphasizing the minister's power to act through his appointed officials.

The case of the misplaced statue served as a reminder to the people of Bridlington and the UK that the actions of government officials can be largely considered as the actions of the minister in charge of their department, especially in instances like this where the minister took a personal interest in the matter.

The department's administrative assistant, Rosa, was responsibile for processing Emily's application.

A year later, a top official noticed the irregularity and sought to revoke the approval, citing that Rosa didn't have the authority to sign on behalf of the minister.

Emily fought against the revocation, claiming she relied on Rosa's office as the acting ministers, and expected their decisions to be final. Her lawyer argued that the Carltona doctrine applied, making Rosa's actions synonymous with the actual minister's. In the end, the court ruled that Emily was correct. Rosa's actions, as the administrative assistant of the Ministry of Transport, were under the authority of the minister, effectively binding Emily's contract and preventing the revocation of her expansion.

This verdict makes it clear: when a public official makes a binding decision as part of their duties, their action is representative of the department's authority as a whole.

definition:
A castle doctrine, also known as a castle law or a defense of habitation law, is a legal doctrine that designates a person's abode or any legally occupied place (for example, an automobile or a home) as a place in which that person has protections and immunities permitting one, in certain circumstances, to use force (up to and including deadly force) to defend oneself against an intruder, free from legal prosecution for the consequences of the force used. The term is most commonly used in the United States, though many other countries invoke comparable principles in their laws.
Depending on the location, a person may have a duty to retreat to avoid violence if one can reasonably do so. Castle doctrines lessen the duty to retreat when an individual is assaulted within one's own home. Deadly force may either be justified, the burdens of production and proof for charges impeded, or an affirmative defense against criminal homicide applicable, in cases "when the actor reasonably fears imminent peril of death or serious bodily harm to him or herself or another." The castle doctrine is not a defined law that can be invoked, but a set of principles which may be incorporated in some form in many jurisdictions. Castle doctrines may not provide civil immunity, such as from wrongful death suits, which have a much lower burden of proof.
Justifiable homicide is a legally blameless killing in self-defense. A justifiable homicide that occurs within the home is distinct as a matter of law from castle doctrine, because the mere occurrence of trespassing—and occasionally a subjective requirement of fear—is sufficient to invoke the castle doctrine, under which the burden of proof of fact is much less challenging than that of justifying homicide in self-defense. However, the existence in a legal code of such a provision (of justifiable homicide in self-defense pertaining to one's domicile) does not imply the creation of a castle doctrine protecting the estate and exonerating any duty to retreat. The use of this legal principle in the United States has been controversial in relation to a number of cases in which it has been invoked, including the deaths of Japanese exchange student Yoshihiro Hattori and Scottish businessman Andrew de Vries.

Title: "The Uninvited Guest"

In the quiet suburban town of Harmony Hills, lived a widowed woman named Martha. One evening, after a long day at work, she returned to find her front door ajar. As she stepped inside, she heard a strange noise coming from the kitchen. Cautiously, she approached, her hand clutched tightly around the antique silver pepper mill her late husband loved. The intruder, a burly man with a menacing grin, was ransacking her cabinets.

"I'm calling the police!" Martha shouted, her voice trembling. The intruder sneered, moving towards her with a sinister glint in his eyes. In that split second, Martha felt an overwhelming sensation of imminent danger, her instincts screaming for survival. With a cry of fear, she swung the pepper mill, aiming for the intruder's eyes. The force of the blow sent him staggering back, giving her time to retreat.

When the police arrived, they found the intruder unconscious but alive on her kitchen floor. Martha was shaken but safe. In court, she was protected by the Castle Doctrine. The law, understanding her right to protect her home and her life, lessened the burden of proof for self-defense. Martha was not required to retreat from her own home when faced with imminent danger. The pepper mill, her weapon of defense, became a symbol of her right to protect her sanctuary and her life, a testament to the Castle Doctrine that safeguards ordinary citizens against uninvited guests who mean harm.

definition:
Caveat emptor (; from caveat, "may he/she beware", a subjunctive form of cavēre, "to beware" + ēmptor, "buyer") is Latin for "Let the buyer beware". It has become a proverb in English. Generally, caveat emptor is the contract law principle that controls the sale of real property after the date of closing, but may also apply to sales of other goods. The phrase caveat emptor and its use as a disclaimer of warranties arises from the fact that buyers typically have less information than the seller about the good or service they are purchasing. This quality of the situation is known as 'information asymmetry'. Defects in the good or service may be hidden from the buyer, and only known to the seller.
It is a short form of Caveat emptor, quia ignorare non debuit quod jus alienum emit ("Let a purchaser beware, for he ought not to be ignorant of the nature of the property which he is buying from another party.") I.e. the buyer should assure himself that the product is good and that the seller had the right to sell it, as opposed to receiving stolen property.
A common way that information asymmetry between seller and buyer has been addressed is through a legally binding warranty, such as a guarantee of satisfaction.

Title: The Used Car Dilemma

In the bustling town of Harmonyville, a middle-aged woman named Margaret was on the hunt for a reliable second-hand car. She found one at an affordable price from Jake, a well-known local auto dealer. The car looked great, the engine purred, and the seats were comfortable, so Margaret, trusting Jake's reputation, made the purchase.

However, just a week into her ownership, the engine started to falter, and the transmission refused to shift smoothly. Margaret took the car back to Jake, hoping for a solution. Jake, looking genuinely surprised, promised to look into the matter and have the car fixed promptly.

Days passed, and the car remained unrepaired. Frustrated, Margaret approached a local attorney, Linda, for help. Linda explained the situation to Margaret, informing her of a legal concept called 'Caveat emptor' - Let the buyer beware. In essence, it meant that when purchasing a used vehicle, it was Margaret's responsibility to ensure the car was in good condition, as the seller, Jake, had no legal obligation to disclose any imperfections or hidden defects.

Now aware of this legal concept, Margaret felt a sense of duty to investigate the car's condition before her purchase. She found a local mechanic who confirmed that Jake was well aware of the car's issues before selling it to Margaret, making the car a 'lemon' - a vehicle that has significant defects or malfunctions.

Armed with this information, Margaret took Jake to court, arguing that he had violated her trust and sold her a defective vehicle. With the mechanic's testimony and evidence of Jake's knowledge of the car's issues, Margaret won her case and was compensated for the faulty car and the emotional distress she experienced.

From then on, Margaret always made sure to inspect any second-hand items she was buying, making her a wiser and more cautious consumer after learning about 'Caveat emptor'.

Lena had been looking for a new used bicycle for months, and finally found a vintage road bike listed online for sale by a local collectibles shop, "Cycle Classics". The shop's ad described the bike as a "vintage beauty" in "excellent working condition". Lena had always wanted a bike like this, and the price was negotiable. She had no experience with bikes from that era, but the mechanic at Cycle Classics assured her it was a rare and valuable collector's item.

Lena handed over her money and had the bike transported to her home. At first, the bike seemed fine, but as she began to ride it, she noticed the brakes were wobbly and the chain kept coming loose. A trip to a local bike shop revealed that the bike was a rare bike, but also had major issues with its shock-absorbing system and faulty gears. Lena was frustrated - she had paid a significant amount for a bike that clearly needed extensive repairs.

As she contacted Cycle Classics to return the bike or ask for a refund, the shop owner explained that they had sold her the bike in "as-is" condition, meaning they made no promises about its quality or functionality. It turned out that the bike had had several previous owners who had made different modifications and fixes over the years, which not all were documented.

In this case, Cycle Classics is not liable for the bike's defects because Lena had entered the sale as-is and the shop had made no guarantees about the bike's condition. This is an example of the principle of Caveat Emptor in action, reminding buyers that it's their responsibility to investigate, inspect, and take their own precautions before buying - especially when purchasing used items.

Title: The Faulty Artwork Purchase

In the heart of a bustling city, lived a passionate art lover named Alex, who had recently inherited a modest sum of money. Eager to adorn his small apartment with a unique piece, he ventured into a quaint art gallery owned by an old, eccentric man named Mr. Cunningham. Cunningham was known for his classic yet quirky selection, and Alex had always admired his work.

One painting caught Alex's eye—a breathtaking piece of abstract art. It was vibrant, mysterious, and brilliantly crafted. The price tag was hefty, but Alex felt it was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to own such a masterpiece. After confirming the painting was legally Cunningham's to sell, Alex handed over a cashier's check, and the painting was packaged and delivered to his apartment.

Excitedly, Alex hung the artwork in his living room, only to find it started to fade within a week. After researching, Alex discovered the painting's pigments used were unstable and prone to fading, something he had no idea about when purchasing. Devastated, Alex contacted Cunningham.

Cunningham, aware that the painting was a bit temperamental but not wanting to compromise its sale, had failed to disclose this information to his customers. Confronted by an indignant Alex, Cunningham reluctantly offered a refund. However, Alex refused, insisting he had not been made aware that the painting was defective andthat such a significant loss in the artwork's value was not what he had expected when he paid a high price for it.

This story illustrates the legal concept of Caveat emptor—the buyer must beware when purchasing goods, as the seller is not required to divulge defects or information about the quality of the item. In this case, Alex should have inspected the artwork and been more thorough in verifying its quality or sought a warranty before purchasing. If Alex had pushed the issue to court, he might have had a greater chance of suing for warranty breach or misrepresentation since the painting's impermanent nature was not immediately apparent and caused significant financial loss. But by understanding the Caveat emptor principle, Alex could have taken more caution when making his purchase.

definition: Child migration or "children in migration or mobility" (sometimes more generally "children on the move") is the movement of people ages 3–18 within or across political borders, with or without their parents or a legal guardian, to another country or region. They may travel with or without legal travel documents. They may arrive to the destination country as refugees, asylum seekers, or economic migrants.

In the heart of West Africa's lush savannah, a small village named Kambala thrived. Young Amara, an 11-year-old girl with a radiant smile, loved her life surrounded by close-knit family and friends. However, the peaceful life was soon disrupted by a sudden war that erupted in neighboring villages.

Days turned into weeks, and the fighting grew closer. With her parents' lives under constant threat, they had no choice but to make a difficult decision - to leave Kambala and seek safety. They had no passports, no pre-planned route; they were migrating due to war - child migrants.

Amara's family walked for days, encountering harsh terrains, scarce water, and dangerous bandits. Their journey was filled with uncertainty, but the revelation of a vibrant city far away, rumored to offer sanctuary, fueled their resolve. After weeks of trekking, they arrived at the shores of the vast ocean, where she saw a Spanish ship that looked like it had come from a fairy tale.

After a perilous sea voyage, they finally stepped foot on European soil, seeking asylum. The journey was harrowing, but they had made it as child migrants. Amara, filled with relief, looked up to her parents and clung to the hope that they could rebuild their lives in this new land.

Years later, Amara would remember that journey as a traumatic yet transformative experience. The story of the young girl from Kambala became a symbol for the countless child migrants who make perilous journeys for a better life, seeking safety, adventure, and new opportunities.

definition:
Clausula rebus sic stantibus is the legal doctrine allowing for a contract or a treaty to become inapplicable because of a fundamental change of circumstances. In public international law the doctrine essentially serves an "escape clause" to the general rule of pacta sunt servanda (promises must be kept).: 28  Because the doctrine is a risk to the security of treaties, as its scope is relatively unconfined, the conditions in which it may be invoked must be carefully noted.: 23–28  
This term is related to force majeure and hardship clause.
mistral_story:
Title: The Garden Treaty and the Drought: A Lesson in Clausula Rebus Sic Stantibus

In the idyllic, sun-kissed town of Florava, two neighbors, Maria and Antonio, shared a long-standing agreement. Their garden boundary, marked by a beautiful, ancient oak tree, was the subject of a treaty, agreed upon decades ago, stating that they would share the water supply equally to maintain the tree and tend their respective gardens.

The years passed, and the towns around Florava expanded, causing the once crisp, clean river that supplied their water to be diverted for development. What was once a trickling stream was now a dry, barren channel, leaving Maria and Antonio struggling to maintain their gardens.

Grappling with the situation, Maria suggested raisingKEYWORD Clausula rebus sic stantibus. Antonio, initially skeptical, recognized the fundamentally altered circumstances. He agreed that the once-signed treaty should no longer apply as the source of water had ceased to exist, making equal distribution impossible.

Taking their argument to the town meeting, they presented their case, citing the legal doctrine of Clausula rebus sic stantibus. The mayor agreed that the current situation was indeed unforeseeable when they signed the treaty more than 30 years ago. Following a consensus among the town Council, the treaty was renegotiated, reflecting the new reality and allotting the dwindling water supply in a fair manner.

While the alterations caused some tension between Maria and Antonio, they appreciated the importance of compromise when faced with significant changes and recognized that the Clausula rebus sic stantibus had helped them adapt to their evolving circumstances while preserving their harmonious relationship.

Maria and Ahmed had been working on a joint business venture to build a large solar farm in a remote desert location. Their contract, signed five years ago, had certain terms that made sense at the time: they would import equipment from Europe at preferential rates, and Ahmed's company would provide the land free of charge. However, since the contract was signed, the EU had imposed a steep import tax on solar panels from Europe, and the land that Ahmed's company had promised to provide had been announced as a national park, requiring a significant area to be surrendered for wildlife conservation.

As the project's profitability had become increasingly uncertain, Maria and Ahmed tried to renegotiate their contract, but the changes in the external circumstances (the import tax and the national park designation) had rendered their initial agreement no longer viable. Maria argued that the changes in circumstances (rebus sic stantibus) should allow them to reconsider their agreement and adapt to the new reality. Ahmed, on the other hand, believed they should stick to the original terms and pay the additional import tax and return the area taken over by the wildlife reserve. Maria's lawyers successfully petitioned the court to invoke the rebus sic stantibus doctrine, arguing that the drastic changes in circumstances should release them from their commitment to the original agreement. As a result, they renegotiated the terms of their contract to better suit the new reality.

This scenario illustrates how a change in circumstances can impact the enforceability of an agreement and the importance of the rebus sic stantibus doctrine in adapting contracts to accommodate unforeseen external changes.

definition:
Clean hands, sometimes called the clean hands doctrine, unclean hands doctrine, or dirty hands doctrine, is an equitable defense in which the defendant argues that the plaintiff is not entitled to obtain an equitable remedy because the plaintiff is acting unethically or has acted in bad faith with respect to the subject of the complaint—that is, with "unclean hands". The defendant has the burden of proof to show the plaintiff is not acting in good faith. The doctrine is often stated as "those seeking equity must do equity" or "equity must come with clean hands". This is a matter of protocol, characterised by A. P. Herbert in Uncommon Law by his fictional Judge Mildew saying (as Herbert says, "less elegantly"), "A dirty dog will not have justice by the court".
A defendant's unclean hands can also be claimed and proven by the plaintiff to claim other equitable remedies and to prevent that defendant from asserting equitable affirmative defenses. In other words, 'unclean hands' can be used offensively by the plaintiff as well as defensively by the defendant. Historically, the doctrine of unclean hands can be traced as far back as the Fourth Lateran Council.
"He who comes into equity must come with clean hands" is an equitable maxim in English law.

The judge ruled in favor of Alex, citing the "Clean Hands" doctrine, stating that since Mr. Higgins acted unethically and in bad faith, he was not entitled to any equitable remedies.

With this ruling, Alex was able to salvage his reputation and rebuild trust in the community, proving that even in the face of unfair competition, justice could be served when one maintains clean hands.

definition:
The collateral source rule, or collateral source doctrine, is an American case law evidentiary rule that prohibits the admission of evidence that the plaintiff or victim has received compensation from some source other than the damages sought against the defendant. The purpose of the rule is to ensure that the wrongful party pays the full cost of the harm caused, so that future harmful conduct is thereby deterred or, at least, fully included in the defendant's cost of doing business.  Subrogation and indemnification principles then commonly provide that the person who paid the initial compensation to the plaintiff or victim has a right to recover any double recovery from the plaintiff or victim.  For example, in a personal injury action, evidence that the plaintiff's medical bills were paid by medical insurance, or by workers' compensation, is not generally admissible and the plaintiff can recover the amount of those bills from the defendant. If the plaintiff then collects the amount of medical bills from the defendant, that amount is then typically paid by the plaintiff to the insurance carrier under principles of subrogation and indemnification.
The collateral source doctrine has come under attack by tort reform advocates. They argue that if the plaintiff's injuries and damages have already been compensated, it is unfair and duplicative to allow an award of damages against the tortfeasor. As a result some states have altered or partially abrogated the rule by statute.  Proponents of the rule note that without it, the wrongdoer [tortfeasor] gets the benefit of the injured party carrying insurance or obtaining minimal benefits through government programs and obtains a form of subsidy where the wrongdoer does not pay the full cost of their wrongful conduct but instead transfers some of that cost [insurance premiums] to the victims causing insurance rates to be higher.  
Nevertheless, some courts have held that the rule ought not to provide a safe haven in a contract action for an unfaithful contracting party.

Fortunately, he had medical insurance that covered most of his expenses, and his wife, a dedicated nurse, took care of him at home. Instead, they would focus solely on the damages his employer caused, ensuring that John received a fair compensation that reflected the full extent of the harm inflicted.

Meanwhile, John's employer, eager to avoid liability and financial responsibility, tried to present evidence of the insurance payments. However, due to the collateral source rule, that evidence was dismissed, allowing the court to focus solely on the costs his employer actually caused.

John's lawsuit was successful, and he received a fair compensation that covered his medical bills, lost wages, and pain and suffering. His insurance company, having the right of subrogation, recovered the initial costs they had paid from the settlement. In the end, justice was served, and John was able to rebuild his life.

definition:
In the practice of international law, command responsibility (also superior responsibility) is the legal doctrine of hierarchical accountability for war crimes, whereby a commanding officer (military) and a superior officer (civil) are legally responsible for the war crimes and the crimes against humanity committed by his subordinates; thus, a commanding officer always is accountable for the acts of commission and the acts of omission of his soldiers.
In the late 19th century, the legal doctrine of command responsibility was codified in the Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907, which are partly based upon the Lieber Code (General Orders No. 100, 24 April 1863), military law that legally allowed the Union Army to fight in the regular and the irregular modes of warfare deployed by the Confederacy during the American Civil War (1861–1865). As international law, the legal doctrine and the term command responsibility were applied and used in the Leipzig war crimes trials (1921) that included the trial of Captain Emil Müller for prisoner abuse committed by his soldiers during the First World War (1914–1918).
In the 20th century, in the late 1940s, the Yamashita standard derived from the incorporation into the U.S. Code of the developments of the legal doctrine of command responsibility presented in the Nuremberg trials (1945–1946). Abiding by that legal precedent, the U.S. Supreme Court allowed the U.S. prosecution of the war crimes case against Imperial Japanese Army General Tomoyuki Yamashita for the atrocities committed by his soldiers in the Philippine Islands, in the Pacific Theatre (1941–1945) of the Second World War. The International Military Tribunal for the Far East charged, tried, and judged Gen. Yamashita for "unlawfully disregarding, and failing to discharge, his duty as a commander to control the acts of members of his command, by permitting them to commit war crimes".
In the 20th century, in the early 1970s, the Medina standard expanded the U.S. Code to include the criminal liability of American military officers for the war crimes committed by their subordinates, as are the war-criminal military officers of an enemy power. The Medina standard was established in the court martial of U.S. Army Captain Ernest Medina in 1971 for not exercising his command authority as a company commander, by not acting to halt the My Lai massacre (16 March 1968) committed by his soldiers during the Vietnam War (1955–1975).

definition: In law, a commanding precedent is a precedent whose facts are "on all fours" with the case at hand. In other words, it almost exactly tracks it, sharing near-identical facts and issues. A commanding precedent is also referred to as a "Goose" case in Louisiana; "Spotted Horse" or "Spotted Dog" cases in Alabama; "Cow" case in Kansas; and "White Horse" or "White Pony" cases in Texas. A legal rule can be "clearly established" without commanding precedent existing. For example, in the United States, a governmental official is generally protected by qualified immunity if his acts were objectively legally reasonable, but such protection may not apply if, in light of pre-existing law, the unlawfulness of his conduct would have been apparent to a reasonably competent official, even if no commanding precedent applicable to his specific behavior existed.

Title: The Case of the Misplaced Paintings

In the quaint town of Artville, Mr. Johnson, the town's beloved librarian, was known for his meticulous work and dedication to preserving their precious art collection. In this small town, there happened to be a case remarkably similar to Mr. Johnson's: it involved a local museum and its curator, who was charged with negligence after a similar incident. The legal decision determined that the curator had acted within his legal rights and was not guilty of negligence.

Now, in the court proceedings against Mr. Johnson, town lawyers sought to establish this previous case as a "Goose" case – a commanding precedent. They argued that, not only were the circumstances paralleling, but also the questions at hand – was the librarian negligent for overseeing the loss of valuable property – were precisely the same in both cases.

Mr. Johnson's legal team contended that, while there was no commanding precedent, prior court decisions held it as a general rule that a government official could only be held liable for a loss if the unlawfulness of their actions would have been apparent to a reasonably competent official. In this case, Mr. Johnson had insurance and followed library procedures, making him unlikely liable.

As the trial unfolded, the court utilized both the commanding precedent from the museum case and the general rule to free Mr. Johnson from the negligence charges. While the fate of the portrait remained unknown, Mr. Johnson's reputation was preserved, ensuring his love for collecting and preserving art could continue in Artville.

definition: Common employment was an historical defence in English tort law that said workers implicitly undertook the risks of being injured by their co-workers, with whom they were in "common employment". The US labor law terminology was the "fellow servant rule".

definition: Comparative negligence, called non-absolute contributory negligence outside the United States, is a partial legal defense that reduces the amount of damages that a plaintiff can recover in a negligence-based claim, based upon the degree to which the plaintiff's own negligence contributed to cause the injury. When the defense is asserted, the factfinder, usually a jury, must decide the degree to which the plaintiff's negligence and the combined negligence of all other relevant actors all contributed to cause the plaintiff's damages. It is a modification of the doctrine of contributory negligence that disallows any recovery by a plaintiff whose negligence contributed even minimally to causing the damages.

Title: The Intersection Mishap: A Tale of Comparative Negligence

In the quiet town of Maplewood, lies a notorious intersection where four main streets converge. One sunny afternoon, two drivers, John and Lisa, found themselves entangled in a minor car accident there.

John, a seasoned driver, was using his smartphone, oblivious to the traffic light turning red, while Lisa, somewhat distracted by her young child in the back seat, rolled through a stop sign as she was adjusting the rearview mirror. As luck would have it, their vehicles collided.

Both parties sustained modest injuries and decided to file a case against each other for damages. In court, they argued over who was responsible for the accident. The judge, recognizing the shared fault, applied the concept of comparative negligence.

After meticulous deliberation, the jury determined that John was 60% at fault for using his smartphone, and Lisa was 40% at fault for not appropriately scanning the intersection. The judge then proceeded to apportion damages accordingly: John was to pay Lisa 40% of what he owed in damages, and Lisa was to pay John 60% of what she owed.

In the end, comparative negligence ensured both parties received their fair share of monetary relief, recognizing the degree of their respective negligence in causing the accident and resulting injuries. Both drivers drove home aware that shared responsibility existed and both played a part in their unfortunate encounter at the intersection.

The jury heard testimony from both sides and ultimately concluded that Sarah was 30% responsible for the accident due to her distraction by her phone, while the driver was 70% responsible for speeding and not following traffic safety guidelines.

Under the comparative negligence rule, Sarah's damages were reduced by 30%. She was awarded $50,000, which was 70% of her original claim. The driver's insurance company paid Sarah the reduced amount, minus the 30% attributed to Sarah's own negligence.

This outcome illustrates the legal concept of comparative negligence. The jury assessed the degree to which both parties contributed to the accident and reduced Sarah's damages accordingly. Had she been deemed even 1% responsible, she would have been barred from recovering any damages under the doctrine of contributory negligence. As it stands, Sarah received a significant portion of her damages, but not the full amount due to her own partial negligence.

definition:
Consideration is a concept of English common law and is a necessity for simple contracts but not for special contracts (contracts by deed). The concept has been adopted by other common law jurisdictions. It is commonly referred to as one of the six or seven elements of a contract.
The court in Currie v Misa declared consideration to be a "Right,  Interest,  Profit,  Benefit, or Forbearance,  Detriment,  Loss,  Responsibility". Thus, consideration is a promise of something of value given by a promissor in exchange for something of value given by a promisee; and typically the thing of value is goods, money, or an act. Forbearance to act, such as an adult promising to refrain from smoking, is enforceable only if one is thereby surrendering a legal right.
Consideration may be thought of as the concept of value offered and accepted by people or organisations entering into contracts. Anything of value promised by one party to the other when making a contract can be treated as "consideration": for example, if A contracts to buy a car from B for $5,000, A's consideration is the promise of $5,000, and B's consideration is the promise of the car.
Additionally, if A signs a contract with B such that A will paint B's house for $500, A's consideration is the service of painting B's house, and B's consideration is $500 paid to A. Further if A signs a contract with B such that A will not repaint his own house in any other colour than white, and B will pay A $500 per year to keep this deal up, there is also a consideration. Although A did not promise to affirmatively do anything, A did promise not to do something that he was allowed to do, and so A did pass consideration. A's consideration to B is the forbearance in painting his own house in a colour other than white, and B's consideration to A is $500 per year. Conversely, if A signs a contract to buy a car from B for $0, B's consideration is still the car, but A is giving no consideration, and so there is no valid contract. However, if B still gives the title to the car to A, then B cannot take the car back, since, while it may not be a valid contract, it is a valid gift.
